awd_titl_txt: Cultural Accommodation And Change In The North Carolina Piedmont
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to provide a new understanding of human health and adaptation on the Atlantic coast during the early Colonial period, one of the most dramatic and dynamic periods of cultural change and interaction in the history of North America. Although the situation in the North Carolina coastal region has received the most scholarly attention, the impacts of European colonization on the indigenous populations and environments of the heartland (the Piedmont region) are poorly documented by historical sources. As a result, archaeological evidence provides a unique means to uncover the unwritten histories of the indigenous peoples of North Carolina and document their experience of, and participation in, the dramatic events and social disruptions that unfolded during the early colonial period. Taking advantage of the unique historical and archaeological resources of this region, systematically collected by the UNC-Chapel Hill Research Laboratories in Archaeology for more than a half century, the researchers will examine how indigenous populations were impacted by the early colonial process.  They will document changes in diet and resource selection and reconstruct how the changes associated with colonization impacted economy, diet, mobility, and health. All previous discussions of subsistence in the Piedmont have focused on identifying what was eaten and how it was obtained and distributed, but not on how shifts in subsistence relate to human nutrition and health. The data collected on this project have direct relevance in the modern world.  They provide a new understanding of the history of North Carolina's peoples, resources, and land use strategies.  They also document indigenous responses to the social, political, environmental and biological stresses of colonial processes, which present a means to assess alternative sustainable food programs in the face of poverty and food insecurity on local and global scales. Moreover, under the direction of collaborating principal investigators, graduate and undergraduate students will play a major role in data collection, management, and analysis, thereby gaining valuable experience in laboratory work, research design, and publication. 

The combination of plant, animal, ethnohistoric, and human biological data included in this project make valuable contributions to understanding how flexible human behavior facilitates changes in food availability and choice. Few other studies have incorporated all of these kinds of data sets at the onset.  Materials from archaeological sites dating between AD 1200 and AD 1720 will be used to examine trends in food choice and procurement within communities through time, as well as to assess variability in resource scheduling, diversity, hunting, and cropping strategies between communities.  Are there changes in plant and animal use between the late prehistoric and early colonial periods?  Are some animals more desirable for European commodity markets?  Do patterns of health and nutrition indicate shifts in diet between the late prehistoric and early colonial periods? We predict that continued emphasis on mixed domestic and wild dietary resources helped buffer the subsistence stress of colonization, while subtle shifts in the way that they were utilized reflect contingent responses in the face of colonization.

Introduction to the Problem

 

With support of the National Science Foundation, we examined how the subsistence economies of indigenous populations were impacted by early colonial processes in the North Carolina Piedmont.   In order to delineate the unique changes brought about by colonization, we also examined dietary patterns during the Late Woodland period. 

 

Objectives/Project Goals    

 

Using a combination of animal, plant, human, and ethnohistoric data, we investigated dietary choice and resource change as two of the larger impacts of the increased interaction of European and native communities during the early colonial period in North Carolina. 

 

To explore these issues, we used archaeological data collected from 17 sites that span the late prehistoric through early colonial eras (dating between AD 1200 and AD 1720) in the Dan, Haw, and Eno River drainages of Piedmont North Carolina. These sites were excavated by projects conducted by the Research Labs of Archaeology at the University of North Carolina and include remains derived from the NSF-funded Siouan Project of the 1980s. We address three main questions:

 

1) Are there changes in plant and animal use between the late prehistoric and early colonial periods that indicate shifts in subsistence procurement strategies?  2) Is there the evidence of the effects of increased desirability of some animals for European commodity markets?  

3) Do patterns of health and nutrition reflect changes in plant and animal use between the late prehistoric and early colonial periods that indicate shifts in diet?  

 

Zooarchaeology Outcomes

Strontium isotope analyses of deer and rodents were done as part of an MA thesis examining evidence for the spatial distribution of deer hunting in the Dan and Eno river basins.  The student found that people inhabiting the Dan River drainage actively engaged in the hunting of deer for hides to provide them in the mercantile trade by expanding their hunting territories.  On the other hand, people inhabiting the Eno River drainage appear to have continued to exploit deer largely for local consumption, as indicated by less diverse strontium values.

Three undergraduate theses were completed on the faunal remains from Piedmont sites during the grant period. These include an Honors thesis based on a sample of 383 deer specimens from the Wall site which generated the first detailed analysis of the demographic and biometric evidence for white-tailed deer hunting at the site in the late prehistoric period.  In addition, another undergraduate thesis described an analysis of 889 deer specimens from the prehistoric Gaston site. This project successfully provided the first detailed analysis of deer hunting strategies including assessing white-tailed deer body size in the late Woodland period in NC.

 

Archaeobotany Outcomes

 

An MA thesis using project data show a fairly stable pattern of plant use across the Dan and Eno river drainages and through time. It would appear that existing gathering and farming practices were robust and resilient in the face of the varied colonial disruptions. In addition to investigating patterns in the use of plant foods, the student examined the distribution of seeds from plants with medicinal uses. While food practices show only modest adjustments, the presence (and use) of plants with medicinal properties increases through time. This would seem to parallel the Native communities increasing exposure to diseases introduced by Europeans.

 

For another MA thesis, a student examined the use of fuel wood at the Wall, Jenrette, and Fredricks sites which were occupied sequentially in a rich floodplain on a bend in the Eno river. The results show that people consistently selected high-quality fuelwood although there were some changes through time likely related to long-term use of the same environment and to factors related to colonialism.

 

Bioarchaeology Outcomes

Dietary reconstruction, an integral part of our analyses, required a nondestructive method that was acceptable to descendant communities of the people we were studying.  Thus, our emphasis on human dietary reconstruction began by developing a protocol for converting the isotopic values obtained from dental calculus (plaque) into those reflective of diet.  Over the first three years of the project, 65 samples of paired bone and calculus samples from individuals of different subsistence bases were examined as part of a pilot study for this project?s methodology. All isotopic analysis occurred in the stable isotope laboratory at the University of Illinois and was conducted by a graduate student as part of her PhD dissertation. Working with Stanley Ambrose, director of the University of Illinois isotope lab, the student successfully created the necessary conversion factor, enabling us to proceed with dietary reconstruction of the Piedmont individuals. 

 

Our isotopic and osteological analyses show that river drainage played a role in people?s diet and health.  For instance, Dan River communities practiced larger scale agriculture than groups from other river drainages.  They also had a higher prevalence of periosteal new bone, supportive of prior observations of nonvenereal endemic treponemal infection.
